para.text: Food and Beverages.

Food and beverages that are furnished by an operator for meals or snacks, or both, shall comply with the guidelines of the Child and Adult Care Food Program of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, as indicated on a chart supplied by the office.
For children in care, unless provided by the child’s parent, the operator shall furnish:
All beverages, including beverages for meals and snacks; and
Milk with all meals.
Except as prescribed for a child by a health care provider, a beverage furnished by the operator may not contain an added sweetener or caffeine.
Unless otherwise ordered by a health care provider or requested by the child’s parent, milk furnished to a child by the operator shall be 1% fat milk or nonfat milk.
The operator may arrange with a child’s parent to furnish milk of a type that is different from the milk ordinarily furnished by the operator.
The operator shall keep a supply of nutritious food on hand in order to provide food to a child whose parent has not supplied:
Food for meals or snacks; or
Sufficient food to meet the standards of the Child and Adult Care Food Program of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
Hours of Operation. If a facility operates:
4 or more consecutive hours a day, the operator shall furnish either:
All meals and snacks; or
Snacks; or
Less than 4 consecutive hours a day, the operator shall either:
Furnish food and beverages for meals or snacks, or both; or
Make arrangements with the parent of a child to provide food and beverages for meals or snacks, or both.
An operator shall serve meals and snacks at intervals of not more than 3 hours apart according to the following schedule:

tr.th: If a child is at a facility for:
The child shall receive at least:

tr.td: 1 meal and 2 snacks or 2 meals and 1 snack
2 meals and 2 snacks or 3 meals and 1 snack

para.text: If an operator chooses not to provide meals, the operator shall make arrangements with the parent of each child to provide food for meals.
Menus. An operator shall:
Post in a conspicuous place a weekly planned menu of foods and beverages furnished by the facility for meals and snacks; and
Keep a dated record of food actually served in the facility, and to each child on a modified diet, on file for at least 4 weeks, correcting the planned menu if necessary.

section.heading: Modified Diet.
section.text: When an operator agrees to accept a child who requires a modified diet for:

para.text: Medical reasons, the operator shall obtain from the child's parent a written prescription for the diet signed and dated by the child's licensed health practitioner within the previous 6 months; or
Cultural or religious reasons, the operator shall obtain written, dated instructions for the diet signed by the child's parent.

An operator shall furnish food at the facility only if it is wholesome and free from spoilage, filth, or other contamination and obtained from sources that comply with all laws relating to food, food processing, food handling, and food labeling.
When an operator contracts to have food furnished from an outside source, such as a catering service, the operator shall ensure that the food:
Has been prepared and processed in a licensed food service facility or in a licensed food processing plant; or
Consists of a snack or party food which is not potentially hazardous and does not present a significant risk of transmitting food-borne disease.
An operator may not provide to the children home-canned goods or any other hermetically sealed food prepared in a place other than a licensed food processing establishment.
An operator:
Shall provide only fluid milk and fluid milk products that are:
Pasteurized Grade A;
Except as provided by §D(3) of this regulation, served from the original container; and
Not more than 4 days older than the expiration date marked on the original container;
May use dry milk, dry milk products, or reconstituted dry milk only for cooking purposes; and
For meals and snacks, may serve milk family-style from a pitcher or similar container into which the milk has been poured from the original container.
An operator shall:
Protect all food from contamination while it is being stored, transported, or displayed; and
Prepare and serve food in a safe, sanitary, and healthful manner.
There shall be sufficient storage areas for all food brought from home and all food held in reserve for service by the operator.
Food shall be stored:
In an area that is dry, cool, well-ventilated, well-lighted, and equipped with easily cleanable shelving; and
At least 6 inches off the floor, to facilitate cleaning.
In a small facility, the operator may store food:
Separately from family food; or
With family food if the operator chooses to have the entire family food storage area inspected.
When food is transferred for storage from its original container, the operator shall provide a secondary storage container that is:
Easily cleanable;
Nontoxic;
Nonabsorbent;
Tightly closed; and
Clearly labeled as to its contents.
An operator:
May not store food below overhead waste lines;
Shall maintain cooked, potentially hazardous hot food at or above a temperature of 140°F;
Shall refrigerate potentially hazardous food at or below a temperature of 40°F;
Shall keep frozen food at or below 0°F; and
Shall restrict the movement of pets and other animals so that food and food contact surfaces are not contaminated.
Single service items such as paper and plastic cups, containers, lids, plates, knives, forks, spoons, and placemats shall be:
Used only once; and
Stored, handled, and dispensed to protect them from contamination.
During an activity in which the children prepare food, the activity shall be planned and carried out in a manner consistent with the safety and health practices required in this subtitle.
An operator shall discard:
All spoiled fruits, vegetables, or other food;
Refrozen food;
Potentially hazardous frozen food that has been thawed and not immediately cooked and served;
Swelled, rusty, or leaky canned foods;
Foods exposed to fire, smoke, or water damage;
After a child finishes eating, any remaining food that has come into contact with:
The child's mouth; or
An eating utensil that has been used by the child; and
After being left out for consumption by children during a meal or snack, any milk remaining in an opened original container, a pitcher or similar container, or a drinking vessel.
The operator shall send home or discard at the end of each day all opened containers of food brought from home for a child.
Appliances and equipment in the food preparation area shall be:
Cleaned and sanitized;
In good repair;
Capable of normal operation; and
Not conducive to the harboring of insects and rodents.
Food contact surfaces shall be nontoxic, smooth, in good repair, and free of breaks, open seams, cracks, pits, and similar imperfections.
Refrigeration shall be:
Of sufficient capacity to store all food and beverages that require refrigeration;
Operated at or below 40°F; and
Equipped with an indicating thermometer graduated at 2°F intervals.
Frozen food units shall be operated at or below 0°F and shall be equipped with an indicating thermometer.
Facilities operating more than 4 consecutive hours shall provide refrigeration.

Except in a small facility or when only snacks are provided by the operator, a separate handwashing sink which is equipped with soap and paper towels shall be provided in or adjacent to each food preparation area. Food preparation and utensil washing sinks may not be used for handwashing.
A cooking exhaust hood shall be provided when routine cleaning does not eliminate condensation or greasy film.
Utensils and equipment used for the preparation and service of food and beverages shall be cleaned, sanitized, air dried, and stored in a manner approved by the office.
Floors and walls in a food preparation area shall be easily cleanable and maintained in a clean condition.
